conversation:
Kith'rak Voss: Now, now, child - your pet means to speak. Tell me, pet: why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Kith'rak Voss: And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: You would've done so already if you didn't want something from me first.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: Perceptive, for such an inferior creature.
Kith'rak Voss: For you to keep sucking air, it is necessary for you to tell me something of worth.
Kith'rak Voss: A vessel fell from the sky. We seek a precious weapon that was taken from it.

Narrator: *You suddenly feel a strange anxiety take hold - not your own, but that of the artefact you carry. Somehow, it's afraid...*
Narrator: *You attune your mind to it. The artefact does not want to fall into the gith raiders' hands any more than it does the Absolute followers'.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the giths' suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is right within their grasp.*
Kith'rak Voss: Help us find it and I will leave your blood beneath your skin, unspilled.
Shadowheart: Don't help them. Don't tell them a thing. We're dead if you do.
Player: I might know something. But it'll cost you.
Kith'rak Voss: You haggle with your own life, fool. Be silent and hold still...
Narrator: *He begins to move his hand in a quick flurry of gestures.*
NodeContext: Narration.
Player: Silently interpret the meaning of the gestures.
: True
Narrator: *You realise he's casting Detect Thoughts.*
Player: Attack.

Kith'rak Voss: What easy prey you make, walking right within my blade's embrace.
Kith'rak Voss: These creatures are so simple to ensnare, Baretha. You mewl too much about your task.
Sarth Baretha: Forgiveness, Kith'rak.
Kith'rak Voss: And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: Can't you muster a real threat, like flaying or blinding?
Kith'rak Voss: Chk! I can devise torments beyond your reckoning, rest assured. But time is pressing.
Kith'rak Voss: For you to keep sucking air, it is necessary for you to tell me something of worth.
Kith'rak Voss: A vessel fell from the sky. We seek a precious weapon that was taken from it.

Narrator: *You feel Shadowheart's anxiety. The weapon that Voss seeks is the same one the Absolute's followers are hunting - it's the artefact that she carries.*
InternalNodeContext: This node if the 'find the weapon' beat was previously delivered by Dror Ragzlin
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the giths' suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is right within their grasp.*
Kith'rak Voss: Help us find it and I will leave your blood beneath your skin, unspilled.
Shadowheart: Don't help them. Don't tell them a thing. We're dead if you do.
Player: You'll need to start from the beginning - what is this weapon you're after?
Kith'rak Voss: Do not speak. Your bleating offends my ears. Just stand still...
Narrator: *He begins to move his hand in a quick flurry of gestures.*
NodeContext: Narration.
Player: Silently interpret the meaning of the gestures.
: True
Narrator: *You realise he's casting Detect Thoughts.*
Player: Attack.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I don't want a crumb left on that plate, girl.
NodeContext: Cheerful granny voice - you're merrily ordering Mayrina about
Mayrina: Auntie Ethel, please. One more bite and this pie is gonna come back up to say hello.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Don't make me get the wooden spoon. You're eating for two, so get to it!
NodeContext: A cheery rhythm to your voice even at the steel to your tone. You will be obeyed.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Ah, if it isn't my favourite flower! Welcome to Auntie Ethel's. Come in - come in!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Feel free to relax yourself and have a cuppa, hm?
Player: Interesting place you have, right in the middle of nowhere.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Beautiful, isn't it? It's my little refuge for the lost and hopeless.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: People in dire need travel from all over Faerûn to see little ol' me. And I do my damndest to help them.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: And you, petal - well, you need a lot of help.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That wriggler swimming in your brain juice is a bit of an inconvenience, isn't it?
Player: That's none of your concern.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: No, but it is yours. And if I were you, I would be very concerned.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I can tell you're almost done cooking. You know you could turn - just like that.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: What do you say? Want me to take care of the little bugger?
Player: Such things are rarely done for free. What's the real bargain here?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You're a sharp one. I am proposing a deal, but it's different from your little pact. You see, I prefer personal things.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: One of your pretty little peepers.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I'll pluck it from your head, kiss it for luck, then back in it goes. Won't take but a moment.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: That is my price. Nothing more, nothing less.
Player: You have a deal.

Kith'rak Voss: What easy prey you make, walking right within my blade's embrace.
Kith'rak Voss: These creatures are so simple to ensnare, Baretha. You mewl too much about your task.
Sarth Baretha: Forgiveness, Kith'rak.
Kith'rak Voss: And as for you, tell me - why shouldn't I run you through this instant?
Player: I don't know you. I pose no threat.
: True
Kith'rak Voss: Of course you are not a threat! You are nothing until I tell you otherwise.
Kith'rak Voss: For you to keep sucking air, it is necessary for you to tell me something of worth.
Kith'rak Voss: A vessel fell from the sky. We seek a precious weapon that was taken from it.

Narrator: *You realise that the weapon Voss speaks of is the gith artefact you carry. You cannot let him discover it - no matter what.*
Narrator: *Her mind focuses - the giths' suspicion cannot be aroused. They cannot discover that the weapon they seek is right within their grasp.*
Kith'rak Voss: Help us find it and I will leave your blood beneath your skin, unspilled.
Shadowheart: Don't help them. Don't tell them a thing. We're dead if you do.
Player: Lie. Claim you saw bandits loot a wreck, then set off to the west.
Kith'rak Voss: Oh you saw something, did you? Let us see exactly what these bandits took...
Narrator: *He begins to move his hand in a quick flurry of gestures.*
NodeContext: Narration.
Player: Silently interpret the meaning of the gestures.
: True
Narrator: *You realise he's casting Detect Thoughts.*
Player: Attack.

Nightsong: Balthazar. Come to add more bars to my cage.
Nightsong: Or perhaps to lead this would-be Justiciar's blade directly to my heart?
Nightsong: I invite you: heap more sins upon your head. My retribution will be all the sweeter for them.
NodeContext: With a deep, seething foreboding
Balthazar: All this time, and you still fail to appreciate the gifts I bestowed on you, Aylin. Sad, to see a thing of beauty not recognise its own worth.
NodeContext: A little displeased and admonishing
Balthazar: But General Thorm - he appreciates you. And he wants you close at hand, so I am here to whisk you back to him.
NodeContext: Tone brightening up a little
Nightsong: Ketheric. I welcome the sight of him, after these hundred years. He whose immortality I supply with my very soul.
Balthazar: General. Thorm. I'm sure you'll be on your best behaviour for him. But just in case, I've taken some precautions.
Balthazar: Keep back. It will take quite some concentration to secure Aylin for her little journey.
Shadowheart: The Nightsong is Shar's sacrifice - she's my destiny. He cannot have her!
Shar: Stop him. Nightsong must not leave. She must die by my spear, or you will have failed me.
NodeContext: Urgent
Nightwarden Minthara: I stand with you, Shadowheart. Slay the Nightsong, and take your place as a Dark Justiciar.
Narrator: *Do as Shar wishes, and you will become Her chosen, but the Absolute cult will know you are its enemy.*
Player: My companion has her own plans for this one. Stand down.
Balthazar: Plans. The drone plans to court the queen bee - yet it dies all the same. Aylin is mine - an aasimar bound to a soulcage of my creation. Lending her immortal strength to General Thorm.
Balthazar: Her power, his will, and my genius. An unsurpassable feat.
Nightsong: Ramblings most unsane. Poor Balthazar, for maggots ate his brain long ago.
NodeContext: A mirthless humor in her voice
Balthazar: Hold your tongue, Aylin. Or I'll take it away from you again. And you - no more questions. No more interference.
NodeContext: First line to Nightsong, second to player.
Player: Go on, then. Take the Nightsong to Ketheric. Get it over with.
Balthazar: Get it over with? No, this is to be savoured. Return to Moonrise Towers - I'm sure we'll find further use for you there.
NodeContext: Addressed to the player
Balthazar: Now don't struggle, Aylin. Well... maybe struggle a little.
NodeContext: Spoken with some relish
Nightsong: A pleasure to have made your acquaintance, little warrior. We will meet again. I am eternal; I will be free, one day; and I never forget a face.
Nightsong: Until then.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Balthazar performs the ritual that transports him and Nightsong to Moonrise
Shadowheart: What have you done?! Her fate was mine to decide!

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: My past is none of your concern.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: No offence intended, just being friendly. You won't find many make others making the effort.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: I didn't come looking for handouts. I take care of myself.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: That might be the simplest approach. Unfortunately, not everyone sees things that way.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: If the refugees have more than they need, it's only fair they give some back.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. But will they share? Not a chance.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Those refugees have been leeching on our city for too long. If we don't show them we mean business, they'll bleed us dry.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: Both sides need teaching a lesson: let's kill them all.

Havkelaag: Ah, a surface dweller.
Havkelaag: You find yourself in the cradle of all knowledge relating to the Underdark: the Society of Brilliance.
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I met an expeditioner claiming to work for you. She sought a githyanki egg.
Havkelaag: Yes, dear Lady Esther. One of our most reliable contractors, though unfortunately this particular request was too much even for her.
Havkelaag: I believe she quite lost her senses over the task. She came here insisting I purchase an owlbear egg from her, of all things.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you've stumbled across any githyanki eggs during your travels? The Society will compensate you for any we purchase, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. The githyanki have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: You yourself have no doubt experienced the prejudice of those who assume that, as beings of the Underdark, we are inherently evil.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: A worthwhile aspiration. You're welcome to the egg.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

Zethino: This city of stone and steel is an endless scream in nature's womb. I have felt no peace here. Until now.
Zethino: Your eyes, stira. There is pain, endless and deep. But also devotion - blazing like the sun. You're in love, are you not?
Player: I have no time for love.
Zethino: Love blossoms in life's furies - you have formed bonds in this time, have you not? Trust. Respect. These are clothes that love dresses in.
Zethino: You are wise to admit it. When it comes to love, vulnerability is armour. Truth, a sword. And trust, a shield. I pray you wield all three, stira.
Zethino: Bring the one you love to me. I will look into your hearts and see if your love is eternal. Or doomed eternally. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Player: This sounds like fun, Wyll. Want to try?
Wyll: I'm more than game. Let's do it.
Zethino: I see you. I see the bond between you. So tender. So fragile. But do you see it for yourselves?
Zethino: Shadowheart: an endless storm surges behind sharp eyes.
Zethino: Listen. Think. From where does Shadowheart draw comfort on a cold, dark night?
Player: The night itself.
Shadowheart: I see. Are you sure you don't want to quit while you're behind?

Zethino: Hear how your bond thrums with pleasure. Strong. Vital. Pulsing with affection.
Zethino: The heart craves comfort, but needs respect. How does one earn the dark-haired maiden's respect?
Player: Farting on a Selûnite.

Arabella: I don't see any - wait. Here they come!
Arabella: Sorry. Knocks the wind right out of me.
Player: How about you teach me those powers of yours?
Arabella: Mm. Maybe. But you gotta help me first.
Arabella: Me and mum and pops, we followed Zevlor out here. Then he - he -
Arabella: Well. There was an ambush. Mum yelled 'run!' So we ran.
Arabella: I could hear 'em running behind me. 'Til I couldn't.
Arabella: Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!
: True
Narrator: *You notice the girl shivering in fear and anger. She is not yet ready to hear the truth of her parents' fate.*
Player: Nature's magic only grows stronger with age, little one. Learn to control it now, while you still can.
Arabella: If I get strong enough, I won't have to run next time... Hmm.
Arabella: Okay. I promise to be really good with practising - but only if you look for my mum and pops. Deal?
Player: Your parents are test-fodder stuffed full of needles, little orphan.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: And are you tough enough?
Arabella: I'll prove it. Let me help in the camp, til you bring mom and pops back to me.
Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!
Player: I was just poking at the rancid dog-meat of your parents' corpses.
Arabella: You're trying to scare me... to see if I'm tough enough to make it out there.
Player: Their bodies fester, pumped full enough of quack serums, swelling organs ready to burst.

He Who Was: The air stirs in trepidation - you have the ledger.
Player: Here - take it.
He Who Was: We have it - her lies, her guilt. Madeline reported her friends to a Dark Justiciar and fled when they were butchered.
He Who Was: Well, she flees no more. I will be the conduit for Madeline's spirit. I will force her to face trial.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: When punishment is needed, my hand will not shy from the blade.
He Who Was: The raven was right, we were fated to meet. Break her, my friend - most thoroughly.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Gale: Come now - you're hardly in position to cast judgement on that score, are you?
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: My gorge rises at your sickening naivety.
Madeline: No - no that wasn't the worst of it.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: Yours is a classic tale of cowardice. Were you a character in a tale of mine, I would kill you off - immediately.
Player: You had the means to stop it - you chose not to. You let fear and cowardice rule you.

Nym Orlith: Couldn't get us off your mind, could you?
Player: I want both of you. At the same time.
Sorn Orlith: We will only allow that if we know there is an evening of exceptional pleasure awaiting us. Usually one darling alone is not enough to match the two of us.
Player: Well, Sorn, you sound like a charming man. Let's go up together.
Shadowheart: Should I be jealous? At least you have good taste.

Nym Orlith: If your beloved one wants to join, we could work out something to our mutual satisfaction.
Sorn Orlith: Two of us, two of you. Four gorgeous people.
Player: What an idea!
Nym Orlith: We want both of you, silly! At the same time.
Astarion: I'd like to try doing things like this again, now I'm free to find my own desires.
Astarion: And don't worry, I'll dart out if I don't enjoy it faster than I used to run from the sun.
Player: Great, let's do it.
Halsin: Perhaps you'd care for a little extra company...
Shadowheart: I won't pretend the thought hasn't crossed my mind once or twice... or more than that.
Player: No, Halsin! Tame yourself!

Havkelaag: I say - that wasn't a githyanki egg you were fiddling around with, was it?
Havkelaag: How would you like to sell it to the Society of Brilliance? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: So the child inside will be experimented on?
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: This experiment is exactly the kind of evil you're trying to disprove.
Havkelaag: The pursuit of knowledge is neither evil nor good. Only in the application of such knowledge should one take on any moral imperative.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: And what if your experiment fails?
Havkelaag: If the child remains evil after the experiment is concluded, it will be destroyed. Such is the fate of all used specimens.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

: False

Slack-Skinned Head: Warriors of the mind. Oh, there's some physical prowess involved, but the battlefield on which we truly fight the ghaik is their own.
Slack-Skinned Head: My order taught a psionic technique much-feared by the ghaik. They destroyed us for it, and kept me as a trophy.
Slack-Skinned Head: I never broke, but... I've spent all these centuries awake. Aware. So here is my offer:
Slack-Skinned Head: Use your tadpole. Erase me - and I will pass my technique onto you.
: False

Slack-Skinned Head: They promised me immortality. And they gave it - I have been their rotting trophy for centuries.

Narrator: *You realise the illithids locked her away not as a trophy, but as a fine vintage.*

Daggers manifest in the air around him and plunge into his body, making a gory pincusion of him. His mutilated corpse crashes to the ground, and the blood that runs from it forms a dark pool.

A light glows within the pool, and within the reflection, we see the Bhaal Temple - the eyes of the skull light with flame within the reflection, and a figure moves out of the darkness toward the surface of the pool, where it connects to reality. It is the butler, his hat gone, the flesh peeled back from his skull in places. Thoroughly mutilated and disfigured. His eyes burn with unholy fire - he has become an Avatar of Bhaal.

Arabella: Still can't find 'em - but I bet you can. You'll help me, I just know it!

Arabella: Just 'til you find mum and pops. I won't be any trouble, I swear it!

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Ah, if it isn't the talk o' the camp?
NodeContext: Meeting player for the first time. Knows you fought off goblins. Loud and charming and cheerful. About to congratulate your efforts.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: It's a rare day I see one of you lot about. Thank goodness you came along when you - oh!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You're twitching something fierce, love. And your eyes! You look like you don't know the meaning of the word sleep.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Auntie Ethel will sort you out. I've lotions and potions galore!
NodeContext: Cheerful as she has someone to look after. Hasn't dawned on her that she hasn't let the player speak yet. A force of personality.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Still, you're looking a little pasty, love. I've just the thing to perk you up.
NodeContext: Reserved curiosity, she knows you're undead but doesn't want to say.
Player: I am magic. If I can't cure myself, nothing you concoct will.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You or the dragon your blood hitched a ride with?
Player: Speak of me or my ancestor like that again and I'll incinerate you.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Oh, you're a saucy little spitfire, aren't you? Good. I like 'em that way.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: You've power most can never dream of. I can smell it from here - like iron and fire. Glorious.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: But something smells off, petal. Something is wrong, isn't it?
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Are you all right?
Player: I've been better. It's... difficult to explain.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: Oh, I've seen it all!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: I once had a fella who'd been caught dabbling with a dryad.
NodeContext: Leaning in, enjoying this gossip and story. Dropping her tone at 'dabbling', putting emphasis on it.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: The wife was none too pleased and introduced him to a pot of boiling oil.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: But worry not! I fixed him up and, depending on the lighting, he looks good as new!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: My point is - whatever ails you... I promise I've seen worse.
Karlach: I hardly think a mad old woman's lotions and potions are going to cure us. We should keep moving.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHuman: What is it, petal? What's wrong?
Player: I've got a mind flayer parasite in my head.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Welcome, adventurer! I take it you're new to Rivington.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: No doubt you came here to choose from my fine selection of weapons?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Yes, I seem to have it all. Clubs, swords, maces, bows. Cutting and gutting galore.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Why don't we see if we can find the perfect weapon for you?

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Wonderful. But, patience is a virtue.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: I provide a personalised service for my customers. To make sure the weapon I choose is the perfect fit.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Good answer. To kill is the closest thing to knowing the power of the gods themselves.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: One more question, if you'll humour me.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Do you think you could turn your weapon on those closest to you?

Counsellor Florrick: You might as well lock the cell. You're too late.

Counsellor Florrick: Empty as a stare. A tadpole's puppet, nothing more.

Lord Enver Gortash: You have the Netherstones - they resonate with my own.
Lord Enver Gortash: I commend you for putting an end to Orin's madness - she must be screaming bloody murder in the Hells even now.
Lord Enver Gortash: How was the reunion? I trust you demonstrated your particular spark of creative genius?

Lord Enver Gortash: Whatever happened in that Temple, it doesn't change what you're guilty of, and the rewards your guilt will sow.

Lord Enver Gortash: You can be my equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: We will raise a Black Keep in Baldur's Gate. Then we will conquer the Sword Coast, and unite all its peoples under our rule. But first -

Lord Enver Gortash: Hand me the Netherstones, and we will rule as one.

Oskar Fevras: Wait, WAIT! I'm just a prisoner - spare me and there'll be coin, I swear it!
NodeContext: Panicked, he just saw us kill a lot of people and thinks we're about to kill him
Player: You're not a prisoner anymore.

Oskar Fevras: For you've rescued none other than the artist Oskar Fevras.
Oskar Fevras: Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.

Oskar Fevras: A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: Ah, patrons dallying with their dashing artisans. A tale as old as art itself.
Oskar Fevras: Quite. It seems we are destined to doomed romances, are we not?
Oskar Fevras: She offered me a future, and so in a fit of madness I told her of my past.
Oskar Fevras: Of the woman I'd loved before she found me. Love still, in truth. She was... less than pleased.
Oskar Fevras: I made a timely retreat into the countryside. To paint, and clear my head. To choose, I suppose.
Player: A truly horrifying dilemma.
Oskar Fevras: Indeed - one to split the very soul. But I dare not dwell on it any longer lest I weep.
Oskar Fevras: And we have your reward to consider - once I have made my way safely back to the city.
Oskar Fevras: Say - I don't suppose you could spare some coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some?
Player: I can spare a little. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Nightwarden Minthara: I expected to be greeted as a hero - but the wretches imprisoned me, and tried to tear my mind apart.
Nightwarden Minthara: I didn't think anyone would come for me.
Player: I came here for the pleasure of killing you myself.

Lorroakan: You have a job to do. So do it - quickly.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: So was it you who picked up Nightsong's trail? I suppose you still have some talents, even if you are damaged goods. Where is it?
Player: I might tell you. But there is another matter I wished to ask you about.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I acquired the 'The Annals of Karsus' from your bookseller. Did anything strike you as... unusual?
Lorroakan: No more so than the rest of the volatile tomes in Tolna's collection. I had her keep them under lock and key to avoid any mishaps.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: What do you want with her?
Lorroakan: 'She'. Then you do know her. You've been to Shar's temple. To the Shadowfell. You've looked upon the Nightsong's face.
Lorroakan: Tell me - and choose your next words carefully - where is she now?
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I know where she is. I might even be willing to tell you.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Nightwarden Minthara: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: I hoped you would - we make a good team.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: We make an acceptable team. But there are greater challenges than Ketheric ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: First Myrkul, now Bhaal - I feel like we're in over our heads.
Nightwarden Minthara: If the gods stand in our way, we will tear them down. Nothing will deny me my vengeance on Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.

Booyahg Piddle: Here - help us out. Sez here that 'goblinoids are obstreperous and malodorous'. What's that mean?

Booyahg Piddle: Said he's writin' a book about the Absolute. Lads didn't like that - said he was a spy or some such...
Booyahg Piddle: ... think they've locked 'im in the cells already.
Booyahg Piddle: ... that's 'im, at the party, warblin' away.

Ptaris: It is not my fault they died. I was only upholding father's code. Even he was not strong enough to follow it.
Ptaris: He was not righteous. He was not innocent. His thoughts were impure.
Ptaris: Such evil can only be cured one way. With pain. With torment. And if that does not work - with death.
Ptaris: Tell me - are you a good person?
Player: Right and wrong don't matter so long as you get the job done.
Ptaris: I see. You have abandoned goodness. Like you abandoned me.
Ptaris: You stole me from my people. Gave me to that woman. Unhatched, defenceless. You let me be brought here so father could hurt me.
Lae'zel: A githyanki raised in isolation. His blood boils like Vlaakith's, but he knows nothing of the Protocols.
Ptaris: You are bad. You must be taught a lesson.
NodeContext: Like this is the onyl reasonable conclusion
Player: You feel strange, don't you? That's your conscience. It's telling you to stop.
Ptaris: My - my what?

Lorroakan: Mark my words: the Nightsong is mine. With or without your help, she will ascend to her grand fate here, in this tower.
Lorroakan: You can get very rich along the way, or let someone else take what's rightfully yours. Choose wisely.
Player: You must be the wizard Lorroakan. I've heard a great deal about you.
Lorroakan: My - could it be? Gale of Waterdeep, here in my tower. I'm surprised you dare show your face after Mystra cast you on the scrap heap.
Lorroakan: Well don't stand on ceremony - out with it.
Player: I acquired the 'The Annals of Karsus' from your bookseller. Did anything strike you as... unusual?
Lorroakan: No more so than the rest of the volatile tomes in Tolna's collection. I had her keep them under lock and key to avoid any mishaps.
Lorroakan: But enough of dusty history - I look to the future.
Lorroakan: You know I seek the Nightsong. Do you have it or not?
Player: I do. And I can hand her over, for the right price.
Lorroakan: Finally. I've been waiting for someone with any measure of wits to heed my clarion call.
Lorroakan: It's quite simple. Bring the Nightsong here, and collect your reward.
Lorroakan: Good. Then you'll have no trouble fulfilling the contract to bring the Nightsong here.
Player: Why do you want her so badly?
Lorroakan: I'm growing tired of this repartee, my friend. Let us cut to the chase.
Lorroakan: Beautiful, isn't it? Worth more than your life, too. I bought it from a Calishite warlock with very little of his soul left to him.
Lorroakan: It can bind a celestial to the wearer's service with a snap of the fingers.
Lorroakan: And this? This can keep her in place. Forever.
Player: I'll tell her to come here - just to give her the satisfaction of ripping you to shreds.

Nightsong: Or perhaps to lead this would-be Justiciar's blade directly to my heart?

NodeContext: With a deep, seething foreboding
Balthazar: All this time, and you still fail to appreciate the gifts I bestowed on you, Aylin. Sad, to see a thing of beauty not recognise its own worth.
NodeContext: A little displeased and admonishing
Balthazar: But General Thorm - he appreciates you. And he wants you close at hand, so I am here to whisk you back to him.
NodeContext: Tone brightening up a little
Nightsong: Ketheric. I welcome the sight of him, after these hundred years. He whose immortality I supply with my very soul.
Balthazar: General. Thorm. I'm sure you'll be on your best behaviour for him. But just in case, I've taken some precautions.
Balthazar: Keep back. It will take quite some concentration to secure Aylin for her little journey.

Shar: Stop him. Nightsong must not leave. She must die by my spear, or you will have failed me.
